44.44.text:
SAM: Alright, fantastic.
Let's go give some prize money.

48.05.text:
Okay? Let's do this!
You've got everything, Janet?

50.55.text:
JANET: Got it!
SAM: Okay let's go!

52.82.text:
CHRIS: Welcome to NASA EDGE.
FRANKLIN: An inside and outside

57.92.text:
CHRIS: We are at the
Bragg Farm in Toney,

61.96.text:
BLAIR: For the Mars
Ascent Vehicle or MAV prize.

64.56.text:
FRANKLIN: Which is part of the
student launch initiative and

67.17.text:
for this event the
prize is a lot of money.

69.67.text:
CHRIS: I tell you what, this is
the first time we have covered

71.67.text:
this event and
you're in for a treat.

73.67.text:
BLAIR: We have been here all
week watching students prepare,

76.01.text:
go through reviews and
put their rockets together,

78.28.text:
take them apart, rebuild. It's
now time to see them launch

81.85.text:
CHRIS: Let's go check out
the action.

106.67.text:
CHRIS: It is great to see the
kids out in full force today.

110.28.text:
FRANKLIN: And the weather is
perfect for launching rockets.

114.45.text:
CHRIS: NASA's been conducting
student launch for a number of

117.22.text:
years but this year
they're adding a twist.

119.52.text:
They're adding to
Centennial Challenges MAV prize.

122.02.text:
FRANKLIN: And that is
the focus of this show.

124.19.text:
BLAIR: So, not all teams
launching rockets today are

127.39.text:
actually competing
for the MAV prize.

129.40.text:
For the teams that are, they
have to complete a very specific

133.17.text:
set of tasks. 
FRANKLIN:To get paid, I mean to

136.04.text:
really receive the cash award;
these teams need to demonstrate

140.74.text:
Support Equipment or AGSE.
BLAIR: Right Franklin.

144.88.text:
These teams have been doing this
throughout the week at various

149.35.text:
Some right up to
launch time today.

151.35.text:
This process is known as the
launch readiness review and

154.75.text:
involves each team showing the
judges that their system can

160.86.text:
stow it in the payload
compartment on their rocket,

163.73.text:
seal the rocket, deploy the
rocket to a vertical launch

169.87.text:
FRANKLIN: For safety reasons,
these demonstrations will be

172.71.text:
done without the motors present
in the rocket because you know

175.87.text:
we don't want any trouble.
CHRIS: You got that right!

178.34.text:
When out on the range
and ready to launch,

182.35.text:
eject their payload on dissent
at a 1000', and return both

186.09.text:
the payload and the rocket
components safely to earth.

188.79.text:
BLAIR: Simple really, if you're
rocking geniuses like these

191.62.text:
students are.
FRANKLIN: Chris, students had

195.03.text:
an opportunity to do
their launch readiness

197.56.text:
review early or save
it and do it a little later.

201.57.text:
You guys actually went first.
How was that experience?

204.47.text:
CHRIS: It was pretty nerve
racking but it went well.

208.57.text:
It worked on the first
try and went very fast,

211.41.text:
faster than most times
that we had done it before.

214.68.text:
FRANKLIN: You guys were pretty
confident coming in that your

217.65.text:
system was ready to go.
CHRIS: We were.

219.92.text:
There was no work on
it once we got here.

221.92.text: It was just resetting it up.

222.92.text:
Everything worked as
we expected it to.

224.92.text:
FRANKLIN: Have you tweeked
it any since you got here?

227.26.text:
CHRIS: Since we got here?
No.

228.49.text:
FRANKLIN: If it's not
broke, don't fix it.

231.83.text:
FRANKLIN: Chris, a lot of teams
here are encountering autonomy

234.83.text:
for the first time.
What special things has your

237.84.text:
team done to work
with that part of the process?

240.67.text:
CHRIS: Our initial design for
enclosing our sample inside our

244.18.text:
hatch of our rocket was a
complicated electronic design

247.65.text:
where we had a door sliding
down on a gear rack using some

250.28.text:
electronic servos. As we were
starting to build that design,

253.62.text: we realized that there might be

255.62.text:
a more simple way
to go about it.

257.32.text:
We realized that the robotic arm
that we were using to lift the

259.36.text:
sample into our hatch could just
as easily be used to close the

262.59.text:
hatch itself with a
little flick of the wrist.

265.03.text:
That little modification to the
robotic arm code saved us a lot

268.00.text:
of time and effort, and ended up
working out really well for us.

270.44.text:
FRANKLIN: You have an air
brake system on your rocket?

274.31.text:
Tell me a little bit about that.
BRIAN: Yes.

276.38.text:
The air brake system
consisted of four fins.

278.38.text:
They're cut out from the body so
they sit flush with our rocket

281.68.text:
and it's used within Arduino
using altitude sensor and a

290.49.text:
That pushes the fins out and
causes more drag to help us

294.39.text:
reach the 3000'
altitude that we need to hit.

299.70.text:
FRANKLIN: John, tell me about
how you used 3D printing in the

304.70.text:
JOHN: One of the things we
wanted to cut down on was

309.68.text:
we were able to keep
ourselves out of the

312.01.text:
machine shop, CAD it up, let
the printer do the work and we

315.58.text:
could continue on
with other things.

317.58.text:
One of the ideas we had was
normally in rocketry the fin can

320.42.text:
and the assembly
itself is all one piece.

322.52.text:
If you break a fin, you have
to replace the entire thing.

324.76.text:
What we've done is made a 3D
printed fin can with replaceable

328.93.text:
fins. Essentially,
if one of the fins breaks,

331.43.text:
we can just pop it out
and pop in a new one.

334.00.text:
Also, along with that,
if it's a windy day,

336.94.text:
we want to put smaller fins
on, we can slide those in;

339.41.text:
bigger fins.
This gives us a lot range.

341.67.text:
BLAIR: The innovations we're
seeing here today are awesome.

345.18.text:
We've also seen many of the
teams actually struggle getting

348.78.text:
all the elements
of their rocket,

351.38.text:
and more importantly, their AGSE
to work throughout the week.

354.35.text:
CHRIS: Remember,
this is not easy.

356.52.text:
We're talking about the
Centennial Challenge.

358.52.text:
FRANKLIN: That's why NASA is
awarding big money to the teams

361.39.text:
that meet and
exceed these challenges.

363.40.text:
CHRIS: Exactly. Earlier,
I had a chance to talk with

365.40.text:
Sam Ortega about the
development of the MAV prize.

368.30.text:
CHRIS: Sam, what is the
Centennial Challenge program and

371.94.text:
why did NASA start
it back in 2005?

373.94.text:
SAM: That's a good
question, Chris.

375.94.text:
The Centennial Challenge's
program started in 2005,

377.94.text:
like you said. It
was around the time the

384.25.text:
two bicycle makers,
built an airplane.

386.29.text:
That is the most unexpected
source of innovation that you

389.39.text:
could have expected for a
solution of heavier than air

391.66.text:
flight. That's what
we're looking for with the

395.89.text:
We want to find people who
can solve technology hurdles or

398.60.text:
remove technology
hurdles that NASA has.

400.63.text:
We want to look for that
from unconventional sources.

407.11.text:
pretty much anywhere.
We're willing to see if they can

409.24.text:
help solve problems
to help us do space exploration.

411.61.text:
CHRIS: Who defines those
technological problems that

414.98.text:
SAM: NASA has set up
their technology road map.

417.48.text:
We have a plan for what
technologies we need to achieve

420.85.text:
our future missions and
our future vision and goals.

424.76.text:
We'll also look to some of the
organizations that are outside

429.50.text:
associations, some of our
partners that are commercial

432.30.text:
space explorers.
We'll look to them to get

434.67.text:
ideas and see what kinds of
technologies they're looking

437.14.text:
for and try to merge
the two together.

439.14.text:
It's something NASA needs.
It's something the nation needs.

441.77.text:
We'll go formulate a prize or
develop a prize competition to

444.64.text:
focus around those types
of ideas. We get schools.

447.51.text:
We get all of the
people we listed earlier.

449.52.text:
They have all these
opportunities to show us the

451.52.text:
technologies they have. By
holding up one prized value,

454.35.text:
we might get 20 or 30
people competing.

457.36.text:
We get to look and see 20 to 30
different technology solutions.

461.49.text:
Then we have the option of going
and working with them to try to

464.23.text:
infuse that technology, infuse
that intellectual property into

467.30.text: NASA to take advantage of it.

468.70.text:
CHRIS: You looked at all
the different rockets,

472.70.text:
what are some thoughts
that you've seen so far.

474.84.text:
SAM: As always with our
Centennial Challenges,

476.84.text:
I'm always impressed with the
ingenuity and solutions that a

480.35.text:
lot of the competitors
come up with.

482.35.text:
Some of our competitors are just
using the resources they have

484.52.text:
around their hometown
or home place.

486.52.text:
CHRIS: Right. 
SAM: Some are using

488.52.text:
farm equipment, which is kind
of fitting here at Bragg Farm.

490.52.text:
CHRIS: Absolutely.
SAM: Kind of perfect, man.

492.52.text:
Some of them are
using high tech.

494.53.text:
They're 3D printing the
parts for the rocket or using

496.53.text:
composite materials.
We're seeing the whole

498.53.text:
spectrum of technology, more
importantly, we're seeing the

500.53.text:
solution ideas or the processes
they're coming up with. That's

503.67.text:
what we're really exciting to
see with this MAV challenge.

505.67.text:
FRANKLIN: I don't know if you
could tell but Sam was totally

508.57.text:
stoked about seeing the AGSE
demonstrated and seeing if these

513.91.text:
BLAIR: I think that is fair.
He is pretty enthusiastic.

516.78.text:
CHRIS: It's the first year of
the MAV prize but you have to

519.38.text:
remember they're working
closely with the student launch,

521.89.text:
which has been working with
students and inspiring young

525.66.text:
BLAIR: I had a chance to talk
with two of the busiest people

528.03.text:
you'll see at this event,
Julie Clift and Katie Wallace.

530.73.text:
They talked all about
how this got started.

532.90.text:
BLAIR: Katie,
Julie, glad you're here.

535.30.text:
I know your voice is struggling
after keeping everything in line

538.97.text:
but we're here
for Student Launch.

540.97.text:
Tell us about Student Launch.
KATIE: Right.

542.98.text:
Student Launch is an activity
we've been doing for 15 years.

545.78.text:
The idea of Student Launch
is to take all the Math,

548.45.text:
Science knowledge that the
student has learned in the

550.45.text:
classroom and apply it to
an engineering challenge. That's

554.09.text:
what we're doing today.
We actually challenged the

556.09.text:
students to build and launch
a rocket to meet specifications.

559.32.text:
BLAIR: You say students but
this is a kind of broad range.

562.73.text:
We're talking about a lot of
varying ages among students.

565.63.text:
What are the
perimeters of the competition?

567.63.text:
KATIE: Right. We have
three components this year.

569.64.text:
We've got middle
school and high school.

571.64.text:
We've also got
college and university,

573.64.text:
and at the college & university
level we have two different

575.81.text:
challenges. One is a little
bit more challenging than

578.24.text:
the other. We've
got a broad range for

582.45.text:
BLAIR: Awesome. Even last
night, you guys were already

584.92.text:
giving awards away.
Tell us a little bit about that.

587.69.text:
KATIE: What you're seeing here
is the culmination of Student

590.92.text:
Launch but it's really 8
months of long, hard work.

594.09.text:
Last night we gave out awards
for Best Project Requirements.

597.03.text:
We also gave out a website award
because one of the things they

600.87.text:
do is develop a website to tell
the public about what they're

605.87.text:
share what you're doing.
KATIE: Along with that,

608.27.text:
they also have to engage
other students in education.

610.94.text:
They reach out to
elementary schools,

612.94.text:
high schools. We give an
Education Engagement award.

615.05.text:
There are also some peer
awards. We had our rocket fair

618.32.text:
yesterday where they get
to share with all the Marshall

621.22.text:
employees everything they've
done for the past 8 months.

623.89.text:
We give out awards like
"Best Looking Rocket,

626.29.text:
"Most Team Spirit," and "Best
Rocket Fair Demonstration."

628.66.text:
BLAIR: Awesome. We're
looking forward to a lot of

643.54.text:
CHRIS: Blair, we've
seen a lot of rockets launch

647.31.text:
and a lot of successful
recoveries so far today.

649.41.text:
BLAIR: As I said, these kids
are geniuses or is it genii?

653.22.text:
FRANKLIN: Man, don't get wrapped
around a grammatical axle.

655.59.text:
I tell you one thing, the
successes you're seeing right

657.99.text:
now weren't apparent
earlier in the week.

660.19.text:
CHRIS: So what you're saying is
rocket science is difficult even

665.60.text:
And the students can
tell you all about it.

668.20.text:
FRANKLIN: Michael, I understand
you've overcome quite a few

671.87.text:
technical difficulties since
you've arrived in Alabama.

676.41.text:
What happened?
MICHAEL: Our entire system

679.08.text:
runs on a series of five Arduino
microcontrollers, little, small

685.25.text:
We need a minimum of five
of them to run everything.

687.25.text:
We brought nine just in
case something happened.

690.09.text:
Somehow on the flight over here
all but three of them broke.

693.19.text:
We spent the last three days
staying up all night around

696.73.text:
clock rewiring and reprogramming
everything to get it to work.

699.97.text:
FRANKLIN: Did you pass
your launch readiness review?

701.97.text:
MICHAEL: We did,
somehow. I don't know how but.

704.44.text:
FRANKLIN: Sounds like to
me you're ready to launch.

707.14.text:
MICHAEL: Oh, we can't wait
and then we're going to sleep.

710.44.text:
FRANKLIN: Alright Hayes. A
lot of teams had to overcome

713.45.text:
some obstacles to get here but
unfortunately you weren't

718.45.text:
able to overcome
yours. What happened?

720.45.text:
HAYES: Two weeks ago we had a
catastrophic failure within our

723.79.text:
motor. We blew out
our aft booster section.

727.73.text:
Fortunately our team was able to
come together and within a span

730.80.text:
of a week, we rebuilt
our entire booster.

733.83.text:
We were all set, ready
to fly last Saturday.

736.33.text:
Unfortunately, we had a
successful launch all the way up

739.97.text:
to about 1500' and our
rocket started gyrating due to a

745.18.text:
Like I said, we just
had a week to build.

746.91.text:
Our rocket essentially sheered
itself apart to all it's pieces.

750.12.text:
We lost the
booster section again.

752.42.text:
Unfortunately, we're not able to
fly but this is our first year

756.82.text:
here. We're very happy to
be here. The process has

759.59.text:
been phenomenal. We're here
to show our failures and show

763.63.text:
that this is the rocket
industry. Failure does sometime

767.03.text:
happen and you've got to be able
to look at your failures and

769.80.text:
design around them and come
up with a way to prevent that.

774.27.text:
FRANKLIN: The conditions you
have in Chicago or Wisconsin

777.44.text:
where you test versus
here, down in Alabama,

780.81.text:
they're polar opposites.
ANNALISE: Oh totally.

785.52.text:
FRANKLIN: Are there any types of
changes that you need to make to

788.89.text:
your rocket to
compensate for the temperature?

792.56.text:
ANNALISE: We've definitely
compensated for the humidity.

795.89.text:
The temperature has had some
effect on our rocket on the

798.96.text:
actual pieces sliding together.
We added some lubricants

804.17.text:
to make things move smoother
but also stay tight. We've made

808.81.text:
some ballast compensations
for the thickness of the air.

813.55.text:
We presume that's going to be
different because Alabama is

815.85.text:
hugely humid. Chicago is pretty
dry aside from the snow.

820.49.text:
FRANKLIN: Sofiane, you're an
international exchange student

825.42.text:
FRANKLIN: What kind of obstacles
did you have to overcome?

829.19.text:
SOFIANE: Obviously, there
was a personal and a technical

833.16.text:
challenge. The main challenge
was to overcome the language

836.94.text:
barrier. You have a team made
of mainly U.S. citizens. As an

842.11.text:
international student, I have to
know how to communicate with

844.61.text:
them. That was hard at the
beginning but when you talk

848.88.text:
technical, you talk solutions,
everyone starts to understand

853.29.text:
each other. That made us here
today with a pretty solid rocket

861.53.text:
We could overcome those
barriers easily with time.

864.36.text:
FRANKLIN: Jordan, I understand
your team doesn't have any

868.87.text:
veterans on it. You're kind
of like a green team.

870.94.text:
Tell me a little bit about it. 
JORDAN: Yes.

872.94.text:
We started out as a team
composed of at least half

875.37.text:
freshmen and sophomore students
that have had no experience with

878.88.text:
a rocketry competition
before. We had an interesting

881.08.text:
challenging tying everybody's
talents, strengths, abilities

883.28.text:
together into a team that can
match up to others we know

887.05.text:
who are here that
consist primarily of upper

889.59.text:
classmen and graduate students.
FRANKLIN: But you are here.

893.66.text:
FRANKLIN: Are you looking
forward to a successful launch

896.49.text:
on Saturday? 
JORDAN: We absolutely are.

900.50.text:
We've only made one design
change since then and we

905.14.text:
Hopefully, we've inspired
enough students to carry on this

907.24.text:
competition in following years
and to step up into leadership

910.34.text:
roles and keep Iowa
State on the map.

915.01.text:
BLAIR: I really love it that
these students are already

917.58.text:
thinking about next
year, future competitions.

920.12.text:
FRANKLIN: If you're
a returning team,

922.02.text:
it's really good to
know the lay of the land.

924.32.text:
CHRIS: Absolutely. For
this competition, it is great

926.32.text:
to have access to this
kind of environment where you

928.29.text:
can launch this many rockets
and support all these teams.

931.13.text:
BLAIR: I had an opportunity to
talk with Jeanie Bragg Harvey

933.70.text:
and hear all about how NASA
was able to secure this

938.37.text:
BLAIR: Jeanie, thanks so much
for allowing us to come onto

942.54.text:
this great property, and
hold this magnificent event.

946.01.text:
I'm curious. How did you start
your relationship with NASA

949.45.text:
to allow them to come out on to
your farm and launch rockets?

952.82.text:
JEANIE: I got this most random
phone call out of the blue one

956.96.text:
day several years ago. As it
turns out, someone at NASA had

962.39.text:
contacted the chairman
of our County Commission.

965.23.text:
He had gone on and contacted my
local Commissioner who got in

969.17.text:
touch with me and
put us together. It sounded

972.14.text:
interesting. It is something
I never heard of before

975.14.text:
and certainly had
never been a part of before.

978.08.text:
I just knew it was something
we wanted to be a part of.

982.41.text:
BLAIR: How did
that first event go?

986.72.text:
JEANIE: I didn't. Not having
been to one, I didn't know

990.02.text:
what to expect but all the staff
from NASA was really good about

994.36.text:
filling me in and cluing me
as to what types of things

1000.00.text:
I believe it has been the only
event we have hosted thus far

1004.27.text:
that's gone off as planned
on the days it was scheduled.

1007.94.text:
April seems to be a month for
rain so that always interferes.

1011.91.text:
BLAIR: What kinds of weather
situations actually cause

1014.58.text:
problems from the farm
standpoint for holding

1018.22.text:
JEANIE: Well, the rain can make
it really mucky in the fields.

1022.22.text:
We have a crop on
the fields right now,

1025.19.text:
so that's going to
help a little bit.

1027.86.text:
Cloud cover before or after a
rain event can prevent launches

1031.46.text: due to low cloud decks. Wind.

1033.47.text:
This area is known
for tornadic storms.

1036.90.text:
We've not had that
interfere with that yet.

1039.90.text:
JEANIE: We keep eyes
out for those things.

1041.91.text:
BLAIR: Obviously you have a lot
of land and that is important

1043.91.text:
for this kind of thing but have
you lost any rockets or anything

1047.58.text:
of the years? 
JEANIE: Not permanently.

1050.45.text:
There may have been a component
that didn't get recovered.

1053.12.text:
We have had rockets go
very far away and drift.

1058.09.text:
We've even gone up in airplanes
looking for them after the fact

1062.96.text:
and have found a couple that
way, that did go off property.

1066.46.text:
BLAIR: But you were
able to recover them all.

1068.47.text:
None are still missing? 
JEANIE: None are still missing.

1071.10.text:
BLAIR: Awesome. You've
been very generous with your

1074.31.text:
land and letting NASA come
out for the event. I know it has

1077.34.text:
an impact on the
farm. What motivates you?

1079.98.text:
Why keep being
involved in the process.

1082.11.text:
JEANIE: It's kind of selfish
reasons because I have two young

1087.65.text:
children. The exposure
that they get to this type of

1091.82.text:
Science & Math, I
can't give them here.

1095.09.text:
There's no way for me
to teach it to them.

1099.13.text:
It's a field trip, a literal
field trip out our backdoor,

1102.83.text:
to come and have access to all
this incredible stuff that

1107.81.text:
To be able to walk from team
to team and ask questions,

1111.84.text:
dig deeper into what
they're payload experiments are,

1115.81.text:
why they designed the
rocket this way or that.

1118.72.text:
They can't get it anywhere
else but at an event like this.

1124.62.text:
FRANKLIN: Guys, it looks like
Jeanie is working on a sequel to

1127.89.text:
Astronaut Farmer.
BLAIR: That's funny, Franklin.

1130.80.text:
Actually, I think she
would make a great astronaut.

1133.13.text:
I wonder if she
submitted an application?

1135.17.text:
CHRIS: Jeanie is not the only
one that benefits from this

1137.47.text:
event. We also want
to hear what the students have

1141.54.text:
FRANKLIN: Gregg, what is the
thing you like most about this

1143.54.text:
competition?
GREGG: One of the things that

1145.71.text:
I think makes this competition
pretty unique is the aspect

1148.51.text:
of being able to outreach
with students of all ages.

1151.32.text:
Part of the competition you're
graded on is your educational

1156.09.text:
to have a good group at
the university that

1158.09.text:
helps us set up
these outreach programs.

1160.09.text:
We spend many, many weeks,
multiple months throughout the

1162.39.text:
entire competition reaching
out to hundreds of kids,

1165.03.text:
middle school, grade
school, high school;

1167.03.text:
teaching them not only about
rocketry but how they can apply

1170.67.text:
what they learn in school
in real life situations.

1173.61.text:
It's been interesting.
You work with the younger

1176.24.text:
kids and the older
kids. It's really easy

1179.01.text:
to get people excited about
rocketry but it's really

1181.58.text:
something special when
you see people really getting in

1184.58.text:
to the STEM
programs, Math and Science.

1186.92.text:
They're trying to pave a way for
the generation behind us

1190.46.text:
that can follow in
our footsteps.

1193.39.text:
FRANKLIN: Since you've arrived
here at the MAV Challenge,

1196.59.text:
you and other teams have had the
opportunity to interact with the

1205.14.text:
have you received any tips or
information that has

1208.84.text:
CHRISTIAN: Definitely.
They've been really helpful.

1210.74.text:
They gave a lot of great
suggestions especially

1213.11.text:
maintaining the integrity; a lot
of the rocket components that

1215.95.text:
deal with the separation. For
instance, the I-bolts

1218.58.text:
connecting the safety
harnesses and parachutes

1221.32.text:
and things like
that, they made us aware that

1223.72.text:
sometimes those I-bolts
can spin loose.

1225.79.text:
You just lose a
part of your rocket.

1227.76.text:
They told us of some ways to
ensure that doesn't happen.

1230.43.text:
We're really thankful for that
kind of stuff because those are

1234.73.text:
Thanks to them, we probably
won't ever encounter them.

1237.64.text:
FRANKLIN: Okay, Alanna.
Your team drove down here to

1240.27.text:
Alabama from Northeastern.
ALANNA: That's true.

1242.34.text:
FRANKLIN: Tell me about
your interesting trip.

1244.61.text:
ALANNA: We drove
down from Boston.

1246.98.text:
A straight drive
would be about 20 hours.

1248.91.text:
We decided to break it up
over the course of three days.

1251.45.text:
We camped in Virginia and
the great Smokey Mountains.

1254.32.text:
We've been working on
assembling our AGSE

1256.65.text: in our tents on the way down.

1258.02.text:
FRANKLIN: You guys
parked at the end of the day,

1260.79.text:
set up tents and started working
on your rocket in the tents?

1264.53.text:
ALANNA: Yep, started pulling
all of the components out of the

1267.00.text:
cars into the tents
before the sun went down.

1270.00.text:
ALANNA: You've got to do
what you've got to do.

1272.00.text:
FRANKLIN: What is it about
launch day that gets you

1276.01.text:
our full-scale rocket fly;
pushing that button;

1278.14.text:
seeing the motor
fire; seeing it hop off the pad.

1281.28.text:
We have a lot of experience
building rockets but we had

1283.88.text:
never built such a heavily
autonomous system before.

1286.78.text:
There was a lot of robotics
knowledge that we had to pick up

1288.99.text:
along the way and
learn and teach ourselves.

1290.99.text:
That was definitely a challenge
for us that was very rewarding

1296.53.text:
CHRIS: It is great to see the
enthusiasm and the look on the

1303.87.text:
FRANKLIN: Yes. Quite
a few of them came a long

1306.30.text:
way from the beginning
of the week.

1308.31.text:
When they showed up, they
were missing some parts.

1312.31.text:
They knew what they had to do
and at the end of the week most

1314.31.text:
of them had successfully
launched their rockets.

1316.31.text:
BLAIR: And they successfully
burned a lot of calories

1318.32.text:
recovering their rockets and
hiking through the fields to

1320.32.text: bring them back. Quite a trek.

1321.85.text:
FRANKLIN: Good thing they had
those trackers because I'm going

1323.92.text:
to tell you one thing, they
would still be looking

1327.19.text:
CHRIS: I felt sorry for that one
team that had their rocket 60

1329.69.text:
feet in the top of the tree.
BLAIR: The good news is that

1332.43.text:
NASA today was prepared to
award three teams prize money.

1337.44.text:
Unfortunately, only two
teams qualified for the prize.

1340.41.text:
So, for the first ever
Centennial Challenge MAV prize,

1344.24.text:
the 2nd place winner is
Tarleton State University.

1349.41.text:
CHRIS: First place for the MAV
Prize goes to...

1355.09.text:
SAM: Alright, fantastic. Let's
go give some prize money, okay?

1358.19.text:
Let's do this. You
got everything, Janet?

1362.23.text:
JANET: Got it.
SAM: Okay, let's go.

1372.97.text:
I want to congratulate you in
being the 2015 MAV Challenge

1375.94.text:
Prize winners for
$25,000 in first place.

1380.21.text:
Excellent job! Way
to go you guys!

1385.55.text:
I've got to give out
some more prize money.

1387.59.text: Have a great day! Thank you.

1389.89.text:
NC STATE UNI
TEAM: Go wolf pack!!
